posts.cooked:
I just wanted to see if anyone else has had this issue, and if you have, please let us know what you did to fix it:

We’re building an offseason bot, but it’s still not complete, so I decided to use simulation to check to see if my code is working. I followed the instructions here: Swerve Simulation , and here Swerve Requests , but no matter what I change in the code, it is always acts like the same tank drive. It still acts somewhat field centric, so at least we have that going for us.

I’ll add a full symptom diagnostic soon.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Without seeing your code, it’s impossible to know what could be wrong. A Tuner X generated swerve project and our swerve examples set all of that up for you and have been thoroughly tested to work, so I would check those out as a baseline for comparison.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.cooked: Our current repository for the offseason code is private, so I don’t believe I could post the full code here. But I could post symptoms, and advantage scope readings.

Wait, okay, I might be stupid, we actually aren’t using the proper SimSwerveDrivetrain class, we are only running swerveDrivetrain.updateSimState(.020, RobotController.getBatteryVoltage()); in the real Drive code’s simulationPeriodic() method. Let me see if implementing it will fix the issue.

Alright I tried that and got no where, here is a link to all the files concerned with drive code: Drive.java · GitHub (Drive code and set up)

DefaultDriveCommand.java · GitHub (The default teleop command)

CustomSimulatedDrive.java · GitHub (The simulated swerve code, subclassing from CTRE ’s SimSwerveDrivetrain)

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
First, you do not need to subclass SimSwerveDrivetrain , as SwerveDrivetrain<...> already has one constructed internally. You just need to call updateSimState(...) on the drivetrain periodically, as is demonstrated in our example and generated project. If you want a Field2d with your robot pose, you can register a telemetry function with the drivetrain instance.

Additionally, your steer PID gains are super weak. As is also demonstrated in our generated TunerConstants , your kP is going to be on the order of 50-100 V/rot. A value of 1 V/rot is likely small enough that the motor cannot overcome friction, so the azimuth is not rotating.

As a reminder, if you are running into any issues with your own hand-written swerve constants for our API, our Tuner X Swerve Project Generator catches all of these issues and can generate a fully functional command-based swerve project for your specific hardware (or just all the SwerveDrivetrainConstants and SwerveModuleConstants instances).

posts.cooked: We don’t have the physical robot (so we cant tune pid yet), but I’ll try your solution.
It was the PID gains, I am so stupid. Thanks for the help though!
